Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit with an inductor, resistor, and capacitor arranged in series (RLC circuit). The voltage across the circuit is governed by the differential equation \\( L \\frac{d^2i}{dt^2} + R \\frac{di}{dt} + \\frac{1}{C}i = V(t) \\), where \\( L, R, C \\) are constants and \\( V(t) \\) is the input voltage function. We examine the effect of applying a Laplace Transform \\( \\mathcal{L} \\) to the input voltage function.

If the input voltage function \\( V(t) \\) is modified using the Laplace Transform to \\( \\mathcal{L}(V)(s) \\), and then the circuit is allowed to operate under its differential equation without further alteration, will the current \\( i(t) \\) at time t follow the same path as if \\( V(t) \\) was directly applied?
Explanation: Applying the Laplace Transform changes the frequency-domain representation of the input voltage and thus alters the entire solution of the differential equation in the time-domain. The system's response in terms of current \\( i(t) \\) will correspond to the inverse of the transformed voltage, thus altering the original current path.
